Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Mechanisms of cis-/trans-promoter competition in Drosophila

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit:
Physical contacts between chromosomes, known as interchromosomal interactions, are observed in interphase nuclei of diverse species. In some cases, these interactions allow regulatory elements to act in trans, modulating the expression of genes encoded on a separate chromosome held in close proximity. The advent of high-throughput genome-wide analyses of chromosomal conformations has vastly accelerated the rate at which interchromosomal interactions can be cataloged; however, the functional characterization of their genetic consequences has lagged behind. This CAREER project helps to fill the "function gap" by developing a comprehensive understanding of how a gene expression enhancer will behave when it encounters potential gene regulatory promoters on separate but nearby chromosomes. The experiments center on the creation of transgenic Drosophila carrying various fluorescent reporters that act as readouts for the impacts of interchromosomal interactions on gene expression. These experiments will provide a better understanding of the parameters governing enhancer action in trans, providing information on how the spatial organization of the nucleus impacts enhancer-promoter specificity.

Broader Impacts:
The education plan of this project is focused on expanding research opportunities and hands-on experience in genetics and molecular biology for undergraduate students. Specifically, the project will 1) develop a research-based lab module for an undergraduate genetics course, 2) offer an annual workshop for undergraduate students from a local community college, 3) partner with an existing program that introduces research opportunities to students from underrepresented groups, and 4) provide opportunities for independent research for undergraduates from diverse backgrounds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This CAREER project has advanced our understanding of how the arrangement of genes in the three-dimensional space of the nucleus can influence patterns of gene expression, and provided valuable laboratory training in genetics and molecular biology to undergraduates from diverse groups. The research objectives addressed how physical interactions between chromosomes can influence the activation of genes through the activities of enhancers and promoters, key DNA elements that are critical for all genes to function. Focusing on the model organism Drosophila melanogaster, three major research objectives were undertaken, and all were successfully accomplished to draw the following conclusions: 1), the spacing between an enhancer and promoter is key to determining which gene can be activated by an enhancer, 2), enhancers commonly share the interesting property of being able to activate a gene on a different chromosome if it is nearby in the nucleus, and 3), when promoters compete for the activity of an enhancer, a strong promoter competes well no matter where it is positioned relative to the enhancer. In extending the original aims, the project also provided insight into variation in productive interactions between chromosomes at different locations in the genome, and permitted the careful dissection of a developmental gene whose DNA regulatory elements can interact between different chromosomes. Overall, the research shed significant light on responses of diverse gene regulatory elements to interchromosomal interactions, thereby expanding our fundamental understanding of possible gene regulatory mechanisms.

 

The primary educational component of the project was a research-based lab module offered to undergraduate students at Bowdoin College as part of a core course in Genetics and Molecular Biology, and to undergraduates from the Southern Maine Community College (SMCC) as a week-long short course. In total, 133 Bowdoin students and 45 SMCC students learned elements of experimental design and hands-on techniques for manipulating DNA sequences, collected and analyzed gene expression data, and read and assessed research papers from the primary literature. In addition, multi-week independent research opportunities were provided for 17 Bowdoin undergraduates and 4 SMCC undergraduates; 13 of these students had graduated at the time of this report, 11 of whom had continued into fields involving research, medicine, education, or data analysis. Finally, through participation in the Bowdoin Science Experience (BSE), the PI provided research experiences and/or work-study opportunities for 20 students from groups underrepresented in the sciences. In sum, the education activities of the project had a positive influence on the scientific literacy of a large and diverse group of undergraduate students.
